author: @Pipsicle330

text:
My Dad loved his music, and before he died of cancer in 2020 he became a bit hard of hearing, and couldn’t really enjoy his music anywhere near as much because he couldn’t really hear it properly. I decided to give him my Sennheiser over ear headphones to see if they made any difference. He tried them and his face lit up, he could hear everything again, all the details in the music that he’d missed for so long. He got to enjoy his music again for about 2 months before he died, and I’m so glad for that.

I miss him. This advert resonated with me because it reminded me a little of our situation. Well done John Lewis for doing something different this year, it’s a great advert.
author: @Stevieboy74

text: I really appreciate an ad that acknowledges how regular men think. This NAILS what it feels like to be a Dad in my 50's. I'm still the same person who raved at college to the Happy Mondays, but where did all that time go? I only wish either of my sons would understand me like this guy's kids seem to do. Then again, this is part of the ad's appeal. I showed it to my wife, almost in tears, and she didn't get it at all... It's usually the other way around. This highlights the marketing team's understanding of what it's like to be a Dad of a teenager these days.

text: Great, it's raised awareness, and I think that needs to happen, particularly amongst males, being the most likely to take their own lives in this country, UK. However, this ad may put people under pressure. They are advertising a typical middle class family. The positive comments are most likely coming from this group. If only it was that easy to buy, play a record... for a parent and child to bond. It's not that simple, unfortunately 😢 there will be many parents feeling they are lacking, failed due to this advert. There are so many other obstacles in the way. I'm pleased it's raised awareness, but not entirely realistic for the majority. We didn't have social media in the 90s. We have more education and choices now, but unfortunately the damage is done. I chose not to have children due to the way society is changing for the worse. I'm a 40 something woman and a psychiatrist nurse! and don't regret not having kids. In my line of work, we're just picking up the pieces of family breakdowns.... the very popular john lewis doesn't show that. Don't feel bad, just do your best!

text:
It could be just a Christmas campaign. And, scientifically, supported by a prior study, based on consulting a consumer panel and on customer-derived insights. Thus, technically, compliant. And then, more or less empathetic, with greater or lesser notoriety. And, at the same time, with the assessment of the direct impact generated on the promotional action’s sales. Therefore, the consequent final measurement of the results and the return on investment.

However, in this brand communication, I perceive a philosophical essence or a “human condition” of Christmas — literally, that is, even pre-linguistic: if the human being is what they feel, then let us speak of love. Without words. Sometimes — in excess or at the wrong time — words even prove to be the root cause of the generation gap between parents and children.

Congratulations to John Lewis & Partners and to the creative team. For having said so much, simply by playing music. In the hearts. Of parents and children. Of families.

“Where Love Lives” by Alison Limerick, or the “Perseverance of Love” of Jesus Christ.

It’s Christmas!

text: What is it for people that makes this so powerful? is it that the dad character is maybe partly wishing he could go. back to simpler times, less stress, less responsibility - in the moment at least, before he had his current life, maybe thinking - oh this is great, if only I could go back, but then he see's his son, who's maybe disconnected from him, they've had their differences in opinions lately, but his face just cries out for love after they've disconnected, and the father realises he doesn't need to go back, what he needs now is right in front of him, together they can love each other, be there for each other and enjoy music together. I'm a dad and that's what it made me feel, It made me cry out of guilt for often wishing I could go back to those dance floors when I was a teenager with no worries. I obviously would never swap those things. To live in the moment!
author: @darrencampbell638

text: We don’t always know how to say how we feel Darren ❤️. Not out loud. Not properly. But then comes Christmas and something in us wants to try. This is the story of a dad and his son, and the gift that helps them find their way back to one another 🎁. ^Carena.

text: I can still keep up with the young’uns as long as I got a fresh tank of oxygen and life support nearby, the joy of being middle aged! How I miss those days when you hear your song come on and jump up from your sit. These days you’re more like a demented aged Spider-Man just looking for something to grab hold of as you find your feet and try to get up from your seat only to reach the dance floor and catch the end of the song. Even moving around to your favourite music in your seat is perilous as you butt ain’t that tight anymore and jerk to the left a little too hard and you have silent horrendous smell-bomb violently stinking up the atmosphere immediately around you, that temporarily paralyses you in fear in case you’ve pebbledash your pants!

text: What a absolute bell dinger of an advert! This will mean different things to many people.at Christmas  As a dad of 2 a girl and a boy aged 17 and 15 we do look back at what we thought were the best time and at that moment they were and should be remembered as such with foundess as they made you the person you are today. Life seemed and was much easier as we didnt have the responsibilities and pressures that being a dad brings. It made me remember my late father as well as thanking God for my 2 children.  You have to appreciate the here and now enjoying every possilbe moment you share together, It is hard to try and reflect to see where you started to where you are now in life as seasons come and go so quickly it seems these days.

text:
JL for me:

It’s about the words we don’t always know how to say- The teenage son choosing a record isn’t just a gift, it’s a bridge.

There’s a strong men’s emotional health thread running through this. Men are often raised to 'hold it together', 'be strong', 'say less'. The skill and the compassion is in noticing. That’s what this advert captured for me. Don't get me wrong, I was also taken back to the '90's - my gosh it hit a nerve and I downloaded 'the record' ⁠immediately :D but what I loved was the point about recognition, empathy, and the quiet bravery of care. The link between Dad's and their sons. Brilliant.

text: First Christmas after mum passed away, I used the money from my first job to refurbish a 1960s record player and bought my dad the first album he ever got- Meddle by Pink Floyd. text:
Oh and I’m not a dad, only have daughters… but I’ve shared many a spliff with my 20 yr old who is a born again 90s raver and festival goer.  She doesn’t see me as 53, it feels like we are on a level and she always asks if I’m ok and that in her mind we are both still girls living on earth for the first time. She’s so emotionally mature.. more than most adults.
The Alison Limerick track which I haven’t heard since I was about her age just really hit hard and of course I sent her the link straight away ( she’s just started uni and I miss her so so much ) 
Of course she won’t get the message for a few hrs.. sat night in Liverpool at 20. Defo be out living her best life 🫶🏻
author: @lucyraybould

text:
53 year old here and this got me emotional. Early 90s dance music, all nighters, Hacienda, Quadrant park, Monroes in Blackburn… etc.

Best ad  you’ve done yet  Thank you John Lewis 🙌🏼💙

This ad does as good a job as anything I can imagine of reminding me that I'll look back on these days with great yearning, even as the future brings experiences of its own. Bravo.

text:
The advertising agency that produced this is swimming against the tide, that is for sure, but that is a masterclass in how it is done.

Yes, an English family where father and son are centre stage is definitely a welcome change.

The musical choice instantly invokes nostalgia for the generation X’ers out there.

The tone was perfect and the use of memory of the son from baby to toddler to teenager is powerful stuff.

I shop at John Lewis and will continue to do so.

It is just referring to see fathers, sons and men shown in a positive light for a change.

text:
Hopefully you actually know why Christmas is called Christmas?
Or have you forgotten?
The clue is in the first 6 letters...
It actually means "the one who has been anointed"
There is a message right there, and a big one.

Most of all at Christmas we thank God for the word being made flesh through the Holy Spirit - a novel idea first potentially available from the time of first creation (when All Three were already present then)...

You use three words "fun", "happy" and "joy"

FUN originally meant to cheat or hoax or make a fool of somebody, so a worthless and deceiving/distracting word, as we I think know in our hearts

HAPPY means to have a chance, to have some luck - so better, but nothing blessed or divine, just the way the cookie crumbles sometimes.

JOY relates to being glad and rejoicing, but "enjoy" suggests more of it - but the birth of Jesus is as much joy as we will ever need, and joy is a divine gift founded in love and truth that can be experienced even in the face of sadness and difficulty, because Father, Son and Holy Spirit offer us resilience against bad worldly things.

The word you missed - a great word - is "merry". 
Not by chance do we say "Merry Christmas" and "make merry". When the Prodigal Son returned, the Father ordered all to make merry...
With merry we make an effort to find joy, even if the circumstances do not encourage that - while that might involve more or less alcohol ("he became slightly merry"), it mainly involves spirit, effort, FORGIVENESS, togetherness  - as in the film above. The greatest gift of the Holy Trinity is mercy and forgiveness, and if we can "GET OVER IT" then we are doing God's work here on Earth, here in the awful 1 John 5:19 world.

Try this:   https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mbsjd7tRA7M (I am far from being a Mormon, but, through the Holy Spirit, I look for joy and beauty wherever it is to be found) - this shows the spirit of Christmas better than I ever can.

text:
John Lewis, you've absolutely smashed it for me this year. 

I’m 46, and lately I’ve been looking back a lot… my younger self, my rave days, the freedom, the late nights.
I miss it more than I expected.

These last few years have been rough.
My mental health took a dip and it affected my kids.
My youngest and I have had the hardest time.
My career took over much of my parenting and I missed more than I want to admit.

But life has a way of giving us a second chance.
This past year he’s had his own struggles, and somehow that opened a space for both of us to heal.
He’s helped me.
I’ve helped him.
We’ve met each other again.

And the funny thing is — we found our way back through music.
House music.
The beats of my younger days.
We share songs, talk about memories, dance in the kitchen, gone to gigs
Different generations, same rhythm.

To me, that’s what parenting — and Christmas — is about.
Not being perfect.
Not getting it all right the first time.
But finding a way to reconnect, laugh again, and love each other in real, everyday ways.

Here’s to second chances.
To softer hearts.
To music that carries us home.

💛
author: @rinbeans

text: Thank you for sharing such beautiful words, and it's truly wonderful to learn how music has united you both. Wishing you a magical Christmas, with many special memories and kitchen dances to come ❤️✨ - Nicola

A simple message of love and choice. He misses his youth and party days but his family means MORE to him. 
No box ticking, no wokism, just a British Family, father and son.
Fantastic.

And yes I knew it was Alison Limerick - Where Love Lives for 10 points lmfao.

THANK YOU JOHN LEWIS. I WILL BE SPENDING MY HARD EARNED IN YOUR STORES.

text:
yes it does seem to play down CHRIST - mas, but cannot truly do so, and does not do so.
"Where Love Lives" came out in '92, and now it's 2025 - that's 33 years.
The album from Alison that it was on was entitled "And Still I Rise" -a reference (also) to Maya Angelou's poem.
Wherever there is love, truth, mercy, reconciliation, turning the other cheek, HE IS RIGHT THERE.

text:
John Lewis, you made this Xmas advert an instant classic, even though it’s brand new.

I’m 40 yr old dad with 2 kids. 
The father in the scene clearly reminisces over his youth and the simpler time without smartphones, but nothing compares to his family sacrifice and his baby boy. 

I can’t stop wiping my eyes.

author: @kirstywillowlove

text: ​@kirstywillowlovepersonally im a dad my sons 27. And I get nostalgic for the 90s I was 50 this year. Out every weekend dancing until the early hours drinking and having the time of my life. I look back and think that was the best years of my life but then I remember that it all pales in to insignificance when my boy calls me dad asks for advice or even gives me advice. This advert proper hits home yes those years were fun and exciting and I met my wife and got married but all the years after being a dad and husband are way more fun and mean more. That's how I see this advert others may view it differently or maybe im reading to much in to it and it's just another advert and doesn't mean anything but it does to me.

text: I usually hate xmas ads. They're annoying dull or trying to tick boxes or just plain weird. John Lewis have had some great ones though and this might well be their best ever! This is the message that works, it isn't annoying or dull or weird or attempting to force agendas. It is wholesome. As a Dad of two boys it reminds me as we approach the festive period to remember what is important. My loved ones, my boys and bringing us closer together with love and what connects us.

text: The ad plays around with the notion of Father and Son, while deploying the terms "words" and "gift". The Alison Limerick song is meanwhile "Where  love lives" - a Club hit from 1992. That's a gap of 33 years to now, the typical number of years on Earth ascribed to the Saviour, the word made flesh, the Son of the Father who rose again and delivered the most loving gift of eternal life to all of us. The album originally including the song was 'And Still I rise" - a title that (also) honours the poem of the late Maya Angelou - a taster of various faiths before deciding on Christianity. And so this is CHRISTmas... I hope you have fun.

text: Yep - this has absolutely fllored me too. Cried my eyes out everytime I've seen it. It works on so many levels. I can't beieve we're all discussing a Christmas advert but this is such a brilliant and clever ad. if you're a Dad with a son this totally nails it. I love the details in it...the son is wearing headphones, he's obviously into music...the way he's looking sad that his Dad hasn't seen it...the look from his sister... I'm in the middle of a divorce so this is so poignant... whoever did this ad have just nailed it... i can't believe an ad has affected me so much. Also as someone pointed out, an ad where men aren't portrayed as stupid or useless.  big up all the Dads!

text: I see it as before he had children and a family, his life and joy revolved around raving and that carefree lifestyle. Once he became a father, everything changed-those experiences were left behind as his priorities shifted toward his responsibilities. But through the present and the music, he was taken back to that part of himself, reminded of what he once loved. Then came the realisation that this part of his life had faded when he became a dad. Yet, having his son recognise and connect with that passion-sharing that moment together-was deeply meaningful, because his son is now his whole world.
author: @pt4005

text: 44 year old Mum to an almost teenager and an 8 year old, and I think this is supposed to represent the fun of a lost youth, which pales into insignificance when you have your babies and they change your world - the most important thing is the world you’ve made with your children, everything else is secondary. The son has bought the record to remind the Dad of his younger days, but no matter how good those days were, the days that came after, with him in the world, were so much more precious. And the Dad clearly appreciates the silent gesture, as your children reach those teenage and pre-teen years, they communicate less and less, but the son is letting the gift speak for him. It’s such a lovely touching advert. Probably the best one JL have done yet.
author: @nicolaatkins2348

text: The poignancy of this is off the chart for me. I’m in my early 40’s with a 10 year old son. I pine all the time for the 90’s. In my head I live for that time of my youth, particularly the music. But I often need reminding that the best times in my life are right in the here and now with the most precious thing in the world to me. I think , given the current 90’s nostalgia that exists amongst millennials right now, this advert is absolutely perfectly timed and beautifully executed. Bravo.

text: Well I didn’t expect that! I thought it would be all about luring people into spend spend spend! Spend your money on things because they’re going to say it’s a bargain! I’ve read so many positive and negative comments. I get it. We live in Britain, the UK whatever you want to call us and no matter what, there always someone unhappy or got an opinion. Fair play, I understand BUT what I love about this ad is that JL have approached the Christmas d in such a different way. Made it more emotional and real .. not necessarily encouraged us to spend on their website but I know there will be so many out there who were born on the 70’s, raised in the 80’s and raved in the 90’s and this will be a positive reminder see or trigger to share those amazing experiences we had. Best gift ever .. telling those stories and sharing the music that made us so happy and still does .. I felt no need to suddenly buy from their website .. it made me want to get my tape deck out and play my 90’s tracks to my 13 yer old and tell him about life without phones, social media, meeting friends without texting .. you just knew they’d be there .. the time of that Alison Limerick track was amazing .. I know some won’t get it but I do feel a whole lot of you will ..and it just prompts you to share your good times and memories and have quality time chattering .. best gift ever JL!! No commercial pressure to buy buy buy .. a lovely advert encouraging good relations and just making time for each other ❤️
author: @aliceh1977

text: For me this advert is perfect. The power of music. The power of memory. The love the father has for his son. The resonance is even more powerful for me, because as a clubber since 92...this song is inextricably woven into the decades of my many memories of the scene.
author: @jocksterDJ

text: I think this is rather beautiful and beautifully cast and acted. For me I think there are a mix of meanings running through. I see the main story being that the dad is rather sad and reflects on raising his son and now the son being older. Perhaps he is feeling distant from him or the life they live is not what it was. Burdens of the now are real and life is.more difficult. So the son does what children do best; he shows loves and gives the dad hope by 'taking him back to a happier time'. He then helps the dad maybe grappling with age and to let go of his youth and reconnect with what is important now; his family. The passing of time with its joy and sadness eh; so lovely to capture this for all us parents. The joy of children and love and the sadness of loss and ageing. There's always time to dance and have a hug with the ones we love. The best tune chosen too! The 90s were a great time to be alive!
author: @RebeccaBradshaw-t7o

text: Thanks, Rebecca, it's not always easy to know how to say how we feel. Not out loud, not properly sometimes. But then comes Christmas & something in us wants to try. This is the story of a dad, his son & thoughtful gift that helps them find their way back to one another 🎶. ^Karen

text:
This also got me on a personal relatable interpretation … due to the father of my 2 kids, preferred, putting it about’, going clubbing, doing stuff he shouldn’t have been doing (get my drift)… and wasn’t ever there for his kids. No responsibility given a fk! I walked away! I had to! Thank ‘God’ for my parents as I was a full time working single mum. NB: To add he was never blocked access at any time to see the kids - he just preferred to ‘enjoy’ his life partaking in the above instead!  He caused a LOT of pain! 
Years pass … he is in total regret for what he did, his choices … that time forever lost!
The baby and toddler scenes get me every time!  I would imagine to my kids too on viewing!

text: My son's father is doing the same and lost 21 years of his son's life,  as a result my son is planning to move back to my home country, where all my family who love and are supportive of his plans of new beginning and dreams. author: @hertsbedsbucks

text:
So, an emotionally stunted man has an insidious and pernicious resentment of his (25 year old?) autistic son because he grew up. The son (a people pleaser due to his father's neglect) mirrors his father's awkwardness and is too scared to hand him the thoughtful gift that he naively hopes will make his father validate him as an autonomous person and love him unconditionally. The father is too selfish to do this and continues to infantalise his son to the point of picturing him as a newborn, albeit now at least showing him some of the affection which has clearly been lacking throughout his life. 

This should be a cautionary tale about fostering healthy relationships with your children so that they don't end up parenting you, like in this advert.

Merry Christmas!!

text: 46 year old dad here, I have a 14 year old daughter Grace (going on 18 it feels) and this really hit me. We have a great relationship but can't remember the last time I had a hug from her. It's been the occasional fist bump here and there with a good bit of banter from time to time. For the son in the video to be anticipating his dads response was perfect and then for the Dad to do some dad dancing with the son smiling at the end was great. Also the daughter and mum in the background made it so wholesome. Such a warm, nostalgic and reflective take on parenting teenagers in todays world. Bravo JL.
author: @stephen2nd007

text: Yes, he is obviously a guy going through a bit of a crisis, thinking he’s wasted his life, and he is taken back to a time that he thinks was the best of his life. And then he sees his baby, and realises that his son doesn’t exist in this place. And if he stays in the past he’d never get to experience bringing him up. So he chooses the present. It’s a wonderful life. The present isn’t so bad.

People saying the son is autistic just coz he doesn’t say anything and is wearing big headphones are weird.
Those are professional dj headphones, maybe he got those for Christmas as he’s a dj and got his dad the vinyl in return

text:
I’m 51. House Music was my life in my teens and 20’s. Best moment of the ad 0:31 when the stylus hits the vinyl… 

Class tune - Alison Limerick - Where Love Lives - got it on 12”. 

Thought it was spot on, but, they overdid the schmaltz at the end and it got overly saccharine and cringey reverting to an awful DEI WOKE vocal. 

Why?? Just keep the continuity throughout the advert and grace us with Alison Limerick’s sublime vocal. David Morales deserves recognition too as it’s his mix / production.

text: I always think about this; how all advertising ( almost ) assumes people have kids and that their life is around that. And on top of that, usually a "typical" family of Mum/Dad/2kids which is really not that common these days. I also think about how I saw adverts from early childhood and as an only child of a single Mum, became hyper aware that this is NOT my version of reality as a child and it made me yearn to be "normal" like the families in adverts for cereal etc. I wonder if it brainwashed me to believe that you haven't made it unless you manage to create a cereal box family. . . which lead me to go into alarm mode when I reached 40 childless and made some pretty insane choices which have caused a lot of pain ... but I helped create a little human who I hope will appreciate rave music one day soon.

Bravo, John Lewis - you win the award for Most Heartwarming Christmas Ad of 2025.

text: Ah yes… I was young once my boy… what a beautiful gift, seeing his Dad as more than a Dad… as a man with a world deep inside his soul, a world that doesn’t exist anymore, other than in the nostalgic rhythm resuscitating a youthful life overspilling with fun, freedom, fallouts & fall-ins. Where responsibility was for anyone but us, and life was up for grabs, especially on the weekends…. And seeing you my boy, here with me now, is everything 🙏 much respect to all the mammy’s & daddy’s & the silent discos in their souls…. And for the kids who hear the tune & feel the rhythm….

The people calling it rubbish, they ‘don’t get it’, ‘how’s this Xmas?’

text: I thought it was ace! JL have nailed it. No pressure to buy from their website but encouraging good relations and parents sharing their memories and good times with the youth of today. I think it’s brilliant. I love that it’s not the usual commercial con manipulating us to spend on stuff people don’t need but we buy this stuff as we feel we have to. They’ve set an example of what the festive season should be about .. the best gift is time together .. I am biased as a 90’s raver but I truly feel our experiences must be shared as it was a special time. Not everyone will get this advert but o know so many will. Can’t please everyone hey .. this is Britain! Open your minds folks and see the good in this .. share your funtimes and memories with your beloveds or whoever you wish to .. don’t be quick to criticise .. you’re creating your own misery .. see the good and give JL a high five 🙌🏼

text:
The limited edition vinyl with Alison Limerick's newly reimaged version featuring Labrinth 'Where love lives'  is available today via the John Lewis app in the rewards section. Also available to buy today in-store, subject to availability

All John Lewis profits from the £14.99 vinyl record will support the John Lewis Partnership’s Building Happier Futures programme, which helps people who have grown up in care build brighter futures. ❤️ 🎶 ^Lesley
